content.text: Place the metre rule on the pivot. Place the load \(\mathbf{P}\), labelled \(1.5\mathbf{N}\), on the metre rule at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Keep \(\mathbf{P}\) at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark and adjust the position of the metre rule on the pivot so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced
• In Table 1.1, record the distance \(a\) from the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot
• In Table 1.1, record the distance \(b\) from the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot
• Calculate \(\frac{a}{b}\). Record its value in Table 1.1
• Repeat the procedure using the loads labelled \(1.2\mathbf{N},\) \(1.0\mathbf{N},\) \(0.8\mathbf{N}\) and \(0.5\mathbf{N}.\)
Plot a graph of Weight of Load \(\mathbf{P} / \mathbf{N}\) (y-axis) against \(\frac{a}{b}\) (x-axis). You do not need to begin your axes at the origin, (0,0)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
G =
The gradient \(G\) is numerically equal to the weight \(W\) of the metre rule
Write down the value of \(W\) to an appropriate number of significant figures for this experiment. Include the unit
W =
In this experiment, you will determine the weight of a metre rule using a balancing method
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Close the switch. Measure and record the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{1}\) across the lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\) and the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit. Open the switch
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\) using the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}\)
Disconnect the voltmeter
Connect the lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\) in series with the lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\)
Connect the voltmeter across the two lamps \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\). Close the switch
• Measure and record the p.d. \(V_{2}\) across lamps \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\) and the current \(I_{2}\) in the circuit. Open the switch
• Calculate the combined resistance \(R_{2}\) of lamps \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\) connected in series, using the equation \(R_{2} = \frac{V_{2}}{I_{2}}\)
Disconnect the voltmeter
Connect the lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{3}\) in series with lamps \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\)
Connect the voltmeter across all three lamps. Close the switch
• Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{3}\) across the three lamps and the current \(I_{3}\) in the circuit. Open the switch
• Calculate the combined resistance \(R_{3}\) of lamps \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\) , \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{L}_{3}\) connected in series, using
the equation \(R_{3} = \frac{V_{3}}{I_{3}}\)
A student suggests that the resistance \(R_{3}\) of the three lamps connected in series should be given by the equation \(R_{3} = 3 \times R_{1}\)
State whether your results agree with this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to your results
statement
justification
Complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 2.2 to show:
· three lamps connected in parallel
· a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the lamps
· a variable resistor connected to control the current in all three lamps
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of lamps
The circuit shown in Fig. 2.1 has been set up for you
Use the thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)
Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the beaker
• Measure the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water in the beaker and immediately start the stopclock
• Record this temperature in Table 3.1 at time \(t = 0\)
• Continue recording the temperature \(\theta\) of the water every 60 s until you have a total of six sets of readings of time and temperature in Table 3.1
• Complete the column headings in Table 3.1
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) during the first 120 s
\(\Delta \theta_{1} =\)
• Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{2}\) during the last 120 s
\(\Delta \theta_{2} =\)
Tick the box to show your conclusion from the results in **(c)**
The average rate of cooling is greater in the first 120 s than the average rate of cooling in the last 120 s
The average rate of cooling is less in the first 120 s than the average rate of cooling in the last 120 s
The average rate of cooling is the same in the first 120 s as in the last 120 s
Justify your conclusion in **(d)**(i) by reference to the results
Suggest two ways in which you could reduce the rate of loss of thermal energy from the beaker in this type of experiment

Draw a diagram of a measuring cylinder being used to determine the volume of water poured into the measuring cylinder. Show clearly the water level and draw a straight line showing the line of sight required to obtain an accurate reading of the volume of water
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water

A student investigates the time taken for metal balls to stop moving after being released on a curved track. Fig. 4.1 shows the shape of the track. The track is flexible, so the shape of the curve can be changed
